candidates.title: Cargo update
candidates.body:
I'm not planning on doing a Cargo update PR all the time. Just that considering that grin-wallet had a Cargo update today that will ensure that both repo relies on mostly the same dependencies.

```    Updating crates.io index
    Updating ahash v0.3.7 -> v0.3.8
    Updating miniz_oxide v0.3.6 -> v0.3.7
    Updating miow v0.3.4 -> v0.3.5
    Updating serde_json v1.0.53 -> v1.0.55
    Updating serde_yaml v0.8.12 -> v0.8.13
    Updating syn v1.0.30 -> v1.0.31
    Updating vcpkg v0.2.9 -> v0.2.10
```

candidates.title: migrate to V2 Cargo.lock format
candidates.body:
This PR takes our recently updated Cargo.lock file and translates it to V2 format.

See here for context - 
https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/7070

Tool used for translation -
https://github.com/rustsec/cargo-lock

```
cargo lock translate > Cargo.lock2
mv Cargo.lock2 Cargo.lock
```

`Cargo.lock` in `grin-wallet` was updated in the recent past to V2 and this PR makes Cargo.lock here consistent with that.

V2 has been supported in cargo for a while now and was recently enabled as the default to be used for new projects. Even relatively old versions of cargo support this new version so we should be perfectly fine to switch over at this point.

tl;dr Cargo.lock V2 format should make merge conflicts far less of an ordeal going forward.

https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/7070
> This commit is an attempt to refine Cargo's lock file format to generate
less git merge conflicts for lock file updates as well as make it easier
to manage lock file updates. The new lock file format has a few major changes:

> The [metadata] table is no longer used to track checksums. The
packages themselves now list checksum fields directly.

> The entries in the dependencies key no longer unconditionally
mention the version/source of the dependency. When unambiguous only
the name or only the name/version are mentioned.

Update:

candidates.title: NRD rules and "recent" kernel pos index
candidates.body:
The new NRD kernel variant was introduced in #3303.

This PR adds the kernel_pos index to track "recent" NRD kernel history for efficient validation of the NRD relative lock height rule.

----
### LMDB index impl
- [x] add linked list implementation (lmdb based)
- [x] add kernel_pos index based on linked list implementation
  - [x] push latest kernel pos to head of list
  - [x] peek latest kernel pos
  - [x] pop latest kernel to support rewind
----
### NRD rule validation
- [x] apply_block (during block processing pipeline):
  - [x] push NRD kernels to index
  - [x] validate NRD relative lock height rule
  - [x] test coverage for NRD rule validation
  - [x] ensure rewind of kernel_pos index when rewinding blocks
- [x] rewind kernel_pos index when rewinding "single block" during block processing
  - [x] test coverage of rewind scenario
- [x] validate NRD relative lock heights when processing transactions in stempool/txpool
  - [x] test coverage for NRD rule validation
----
### Txpool
- [x] pool tests currently "mock" out the chain impl which complicates testing of NRD rules (see #3342)
- [x] pool currently identifies txs based on kernel (and kernel hash) and this does not play nicely with NRD kernel reuse (ok for now but should be revisited)
----
### Rebuild Index
- [x] rebuild kernel_pos index on fast sync
- [x] rebuild kernel_pos index on node init
----
### Fast Sync
- [x] validate NRD kernels across full historic kernel set

candidates.title: Update rust-secp256k1 to v0.7.9
candidates.body:
As titled, main fix is: 

https://github.com/mimblewimble/rust-secp256k1-zkp/pull/68

candidates.title: Update Cursive to 0.14 and update backend.
candidates.body:
Update Cursive to 0.14.
Use pancurses-backend instead of ncurses-backend: 
>uses the pancurses library, which forwards calls to ncurses-rs on Linux/macOS or pdcurses-sys on Windows. Requires ncurses to be installed on the system.

I don't think we need the complexity for Windows in the Cargo.toml.

candidates.title: Bump version to v3.1.1
candidates.body: Prep for 3.1.1 release

candidates.title: Include new libsecp256k1 version 0.7.8
candidates.body:
Updates libsecp256k1-mw to 0.7.8 which includes:

* Function to create/initialize a Commitment from a PublicKey
* Implements Ord and PartialOrd for internal types

There are no changes, just new functionality, so this should have no effect on any existing code.

candidates.title: Build croaring without optimizations
candidates.body: Same as https://github.com/mimblewimble/grin/pull/3274 but for the 3.1.x branch

candidates.title: Build croaring without optimizations
candidates.body:
I have modified croaring-rs to support a flag that turns off certain optimizations. These optimizations can result in incompatibilities of our binaries with older cpus.

Because we are not sure if/when the changes will be merged upstream (see [this PR](https://github.com/saulius/croaring-rs/pull/60)), I have published a fork of the repository on crates.io under the name [croaring-mw](https://crates.io/crates/croaring-mw). We can in the future always switch back if needed.

Once this is merged I suggest we release a v3.1.1 so people have a working binary to use if they so choose, instead of being forced to build from source.

Related: https://github.com/mimblewimble/grin/issues/3261

candidates.body: 3.1.0 Release Tagging

bump to 3.1.0-beta.3

Only merge this once #3251 is merged.

candidates.title: bump version to 3.1.0-beta.2
candidates.body: bump the version of the various grin crates to `3.1.0-beta.2`

candidates.title: Update croaring
candidates.body: Let's see if it fix the CI issues.

candidates.title: Update hyper/tokio/futures dependencies
candidates.body:
In preparation for #3206, update the hyper, tokio and futures dependencies to versions supporting `async/.await`. This simplifies some of our code and in some places reduces the number of heap allocations that are done.

There are some improvements that can be made to the different services we are running (p2p, api, stratum, webhook). Particularly, it would be nice to have all of them under a common runtime (instead of creating a multi-threaded runtime for each of them) and add clean shutdown to all of them. But this is something I'm planning on tackling in a separate PR in the future.
